help.p: This self-assessment questionnaire generates an open data certificate and badge you can publish to tell people all about this open data. We also use your answers to learn how organisations publish open data.

When you answer these questions it demonstrates your efforts to comply with relevant UK legislation. You should also check which other laws and policies apply to your sector, especially if you’re outside the UK (which these questions don’t cover).
You do not need to answer all the questions to get a certificate. Just answer those you can.

group.label: Rights
group.help: your right to share this data with people

question.label: Do you have the right to make this data open?

option.label: yes, you have the rights to open this data up
option.requirement: You should have a clear legal right to publish this data.

option.label: no, you don’t have the rights to open up this data
you’re not sure if you have the rights to publish this data as open data
the rights in this data are complicated or unclear

question.help:
If your organisation did not originally create or gather this data then you may not have the right to publish it as open data. If you are not sure, please check with the data owner for their permission.
Open data is data that anyone anyone can access, use and share – subject only, at most, to the requirement to attribute and share-alike – see our page explaining ‘what is open data?’ and the open definition for more details.

if.requirement: You must have the right to publish this data.

question.display: Risks in using this data are described at
question.label: Where do you detail the risks people might encounter if they use this data?
question.help: It can be risky for people to use data without a clear legal right to do so. For example, the data might be taken down in response to a legal challenge. Give a URL for a page that describes the risk of using this data.
question.requirement: You should document risks associated with using this data, so people can work out how they want to use it.

question.label: Was the data originally created or generated by you?

option.display: originally created or generated by its curator
option.label: yes

question.help: If any part of this data was sourced outside your organisation by other individuals or organisations then you need to give extra information about your right to publish it.

question.label: Was some of this data extracted or calculated from other data?
question.help: An extract or smaller part of someone else's data still means your rights to use it might be affected. There might also be legal issues if you analysed their data to produce new results from it.

if.requirement: You indicated that this data wasn't originally created or gathered by you, and wasn't crowdsourced, so it must have been extracted or calculated from other data sources.

question.label: Are all sources of this data already published as open data?
question.help: You're allowed to republish someone else's data if it's already under an open data licence or if their rights have expired or been waived. If any part of this data is not like this then you'll need legal advice before you can publish it.

if.requirement: You should get legal advice to make sure you have the right to publish this data.

question.label: Was some of this data crowdsourced?
question.help: If the data includes information contributed by people outside your organisation, you need their permission to publish their contributions as open data.

if.requirement: You indicated that the data wasn't originally created or gathered by you, and wasn't extracted or calculated from other data, so it must have been crowdsourced.

question.label: Did contributors to this data use their judgement?
question.help: If people used their creativity or judgement to contribute data then they have copyright over their work. For example, writing a description or deciding whether or not to include some data in a dataset would require judgement. So contributors must transfer or waive their rights, or license the data to you before you can publish it.

question.display: The Contributor Licence Agreement is at
question.label: Where is the Contributor Licence Agreement (CLA)?
question.help: Give a link to an agreement that shows contributors allow you to reuse their data. A CLA will either transfer contributor's rights to you, waive their rights, or license the data to you so you can publish it.

question.label: Have all contributors agreed to the Contributor Licence Agreement (CLA)?
question.help: Check all contributors agree to a CLA before you reuse or republish their contributions. You should keep a record of who gave contributions and whether or not they agree to the CLA.
question.requirement: You must get contributors to agree to a Contributor Licence Agreement (CLA) that gives you the right to publish their work as open data.

question.display: The sources of this data are described at
question.label: Where do you describe sources of this data?
question.help: Give a URL that documents where the data was sourced from (its provenance) and the rights under which you publish the data. This helps people understand where the data comes from.
question.requirement: You should document where the data came from and the rights under which you publish it, so people are assured they can use parts which came from third parties.

question.label: Is documentation about the sources of this data also in machine-readable format?

yesno.yes: machine-readable data about the sources of this data

question.help: Information about data sources should be human-readable so people can understand it, as well as in a metadata format that computers can process. When everyone does this it helps other people find out how the same open data is being used and justify its ongoing publication.
question.requirement: You should include machine-readable data about the sources of this data.

group.label: Licensing
group.help: how you give people permission to use this data

question.label: Where have you published the rights statement for this dataset?
question.help: Give the URL to a page that describes the right to re-use this dataset. This should include a reference to its license, attribution requirements, and a statement about relevant copyright and database rights. A rights statement helps people understand what they can and can't do with the data.
question.requirement: You should publish a rights statement that details copyright, database rights, licensing and how people should give attribution to the data.

question.label: Do database rights apply to your dataset?
question.help: In the Czech law system, each dataset can be considered from two viewpoints, as a database and as a creative work. In this question we consider the first case: each database that was creating using non-trivial effort is protected by database rights.

question.label: How are the database rights to your dataset licensed?
question.option: Open Data Commons Open Database License (ODbL)
Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and License (PDDL)
question.help: If you want to publish your dataset as open data, you must have an open license to its database rights.

question.label: Where do you describe the licensing terms for the database rights?

question.display: Database rights do not apply because
Why there are no database rights to the dataset?
question.option: Non-trivial effort wasn’t needed to create the dataset.
The rights were waived by their holders.

question.display: The database rights were waived through
question.label: How were the database rights waived?
question.option: Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and License (PDDL)

question.label: Where is the document used to waive the database rights?
Does copyright apply to the dataset itself?
question.help: The dataset can also be protected by copyright. There are two parts that can be copyrighted: the dataset itself and the contents of the dataset. This question is interested in the first case, the copyright protection of the dataset itself as a creative work.

question.display: The dataset itself is not copyrighted because
question.label: Why doesn’t copyright apply to the dataset itself?

option.display: the dataset is a government work

question.option: The dataset is a government work.

question.label: How is the copyright to the dataset itself licensed?
question.help: If you want to publish the dataset as open data, you must have an open license to its copyright.

question.label: Where do you describe the dataset copyright licensing terms?
Does copyright apply to the contents of your dataset?
question.help: After the database rights and copyright to the dataset itself we are interested in the third kind of rights that may protect the dataset: copyright to the contents of your dataset.

question.display: The dataset contents are not copyrighted because
question.label: Why is there no copyright to the contents of your dataset?

option.display: copyright does not apply to this kind of content

question.option: Copyright does not apply to this kind of content.
The dataset contents are public domain.

option.display: the contents are a government work

question.option: The dataset contents are a government work.

question.label: How is the copyright to the dataset contents licensed?
Where do you describe the licensing terms for the copyright to the dataset contents?

question.display: The rights statement includes data about
question.label: Does your rights statement include machine-readable versions of

option.label: data licence
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the licence for this data, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: content licence
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the licence for the content of this data, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: attribution text
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the text to use when citing the data, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: attribution URL
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the URL to link to when citing this data, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: copyright notice or statement
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the copyright statement or notice of this data, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: copyright year
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the copyright year for the data, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: copyright holder
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the copyright holder for the data, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: database right year
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the database right year for the data, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: database right holder
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the database right holder for the data, so automatic tools can use it.

question.help: It's good practice to embed information about rights in machine-readable formats so people can automatically attribute this data back to you when they use it.

question.label: Can individuals be identified from this data?

option.label: no, the data is not about people or their activities
option.help: Remember that individuals can still be identified even if data isn't directly about them. For example, road traffic flow data combined with an individual's commuting patterns could reveal information about that person.

option.label: no, the data has been anonymised by aggregating individuals into groups, so they can't be distinguished from other people in the group
option.help: Statistical disclosure controls can help to make sure that individuals are not identifiable within aggregate data.

option.label: yes, there is a risk that individuals be identified, for example by third parties with access to extra information
option.help: Some data is legitimately about individuals like civil service pay or public expenses for example.

question.label: Has your anonymisation process been independently audited?
question.requirement: You should have your anonymisation process audited independently to ensure it reduces the risk of individuals being reidentified.

question.display: This data about individuals has been
question.label: Have you attempted to reduce or remove the possibility of individuals being identified?
question.help: Anonymisation reduces the risk of individuals being identified from the data you publish. The best technique to use depends on the kind of data you have.

question.display: By law, this data about individuals
question.label: Are you required or permitted by law to publish this data about individuals?
question.help: The law might require you to publish data about people, such as the names of company directors. Or you might have permission from the affected individuals to publish information about them.
question.requirement: You should only publish personal data without anonymisation if you are required or permitted to do so by law.

question.display: The right to publish this data about individuals is documented at
question.label: Where do you document your right to publish data about individuals?
question.requirement: You should document your right to publish data about individuals for people who use your data and for those affected by disclosure.

question.label: Have you carried out a Privacy Impact Assessment?

yesno.yes: carried out a Privacy Impact Assessment
yesno.no: not carried out a Privacy Impact Assessment

question.help: A Privacy Impact Assessment is how you measure risks to the privacy of individuals in your data as well as the use and disclosure of that information.
question.requirement: You should do a Privacy Impact Assessment if you publish data about individuals.

question.display: The Privacy Impact Assessment is published at
question.label: Where is your Privacy Impact Assessment published?
question.help: Give a URL to where people can check how you have assessed the privacy risks to individuals. This may be redacted or summarised if it contains sensitive information.
question.requirement: You should publish your Privacy Impact Assessment so people can understand how you have assessed the risks of disclosing data.

question.display: The Privacy Impact Assessment has been
question.label: Has your Privacy Impact Assessment been independently audited?
question.help: It's good practice to check your assessment was done correctly. Independent audits by specialists or third-parties tend to be more rigorous and impartial.
question.requirement: You should have your Privacy Impact Assessment audited independently to ensure it has been carried out correctly.

question.display: Individuals affected by this data have this privacy notice
question.label: Where is the privacy notice for individuals affected by your data?
question.help: When you collect data about individuals you must tell them how that data will be used. People who use your data need this to make sure they comply with the Data Protection Act.
question.requirement: You should tell people what purposes the individuals in your data consented to you using their data for. So that they use your data for the same purposes and comply with the Data Protection Act.

question.label: Is there someone in your organisation who is responsible for data protection?

question.display: The individual responsible for data protection
question.label: Have you involved them in the Privacy Impact Assessment process?
question.requirement: You should involve the person responsible for data protection in your organisation before you publish this data.

question.display: The anonymisation of the data has been
question.label: Has your anonymisation approach been independently audited?
question.help: It is good practice to make sure your process to remove personal identifiable data works properly. Independent audits by specialists or third-parties tend to be more rigorous and impartial.
question.requirement: You should have your anonymisation process audited independently by an expert to ensure it is appropriate for your data.
